review.title: Gradient-based Taxis Algorithms for Network Robotics
review.abstract: Finding the physical location of a specific network node is a prototypical task for navigation inside a wireless network. In this paper, we consider in depth the implications of wireless communication as a measurement input of gradient-based taxis algorithms. We discuss how gradients can be measured and determine the errors of this estimation. We then introduce a gradient-based taxis algorithm as an example of a family of gradient-based, convergent algorithms and discuss its convergence in the context of network robotics. We also conduct an exemplary experiment to show how to overcome some of the specific problems related to network robotics. Finally, we show how to adapt this framework to more complex objectives.

HafnerHumboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Institute for Informatics Cognitive Robotics, Berlin, Germany E-mail: blum @ informatik.hu-berlin.deDetermining the physical location of a particular network node is a prototypical task for navigation within a wireless network. In this paper we will examine in detail the implications of wireless communication as a measurement of gradient-based taxis algorithms. We will discuss how gradients can be measured and the errors of this estimation can be determined. We will then present a gradient-based taxis algorithm as an example of a family of gradient-based convergent algorithms and discuss their convergence in the context of network robotics. We will also conduct an example experiment to show how specific problems can be solved by robotics.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Wireless networks, ranging from cellular networks to ad hoc networks used in car-to-car communication, are becoming a critical part of our communications infrastructure. In addition, the paradigm shift to the Internet of Things will equip many physical objects with wireless networking capabilities that will then be able to begin communicating from machine to machine [1]. These connections, in turn, can include entire (ad hoc) wireless networks between these networked objects, one example of which are sensor networks already in use today. In many scenarios for robotic applications, such as utilizing the sensor capacities of a decentralized sensor network or accessing cloud-based resources, robots must be able to integrate into various wireless networks. In addition to these machine-to-machine communication scenarios, mobile robots may also be nodes of very flexible, easy-to-deploy wireless communication networks that can be used as communication infrastructure.

sections.heading: 1.1 Problem Statement
sections.text: In this paper, we consider a very basic, yet very relevant, task for the robot. Finding the physical location of a particular network node is the prototype task for many tasks related to navigation within a wireless network. Later in this paper, we will show how to adapt the presented framework to cope with more complex objectives. A robot receives packets from the network node, which are found in different spatial positions, and measures the signal strength of these packets as a scalar measurement, scanning a scalar field at different points in space. The robot has no means to detect the direction from which the packets arrive, as would be possible with a directional antenna. Furthermore, it cannot measure the time flight of the packets, which would enable the robot to simply trilateralize the source. While both options are technologically feasible, we will not consider them here to be independent of additional technology and hardware, as they would be required for flight time measurement.

sections.heading: 1.2 Related Work
sections.text: A similar problem exists in nature, for example, in the form of chemotherapy [4], in which the bacteria penetrate to the highest concentrations of food (or to the lowest concentrations of food).

sections.heading: 2 Physical Model
sections.text: We discuss in detail the underlying physical models for displacement losses. This forms the basis for the discussion of the algorithm itself and is of universal importance for all network robotics algorithms.

sections.heading: 3.3 Motor Noise: Measurement Errors
sections.text: For a real robot, in addition to the physical measurement noises, as in (5), there is so-called motor noise. This noise is added to every motor command and thus influences all movements. In general, this noise is vector and affects every infinitely small movement of the robot, which results in a random, running-like behavior. This behavior is graphically represented in the input of Fig. 2. Since it makes no qualitative difference to our argument 1, but simplifies the notation, we abstract here from this vector noise only to a sound in the direction of motion. For the central differences, this means that f (~ x) is not sampled at f (~ x + h ~ ei), but at f (~ x + h ~ ei), but at f (h + h + h).

sections.heading: 4 Taxis Algorithm
sections.text: The robot estimates gradients based on finite differences by scanning the scalar field and uses this gradient as direction for the next step. We formally present this algorithm and discuss its convergence and statistical properties.

sections.heading: 4.1 Finite Difference Stochastic Approximation
sections.text: One of the most basic algorithms for finding the minimum of a scalar field is the method of the steepest descent. It consists of the calculation (or in this case estimation) of the gradient ~ gmes (~ x), which begins at a certain starting point ~ x0 and follows it with a certain increment ak: ~ xk + 1 = ~ xk + ak ~ gmes (~ xk). (20) The increments h of the gradient estimate (9) can also be adjusted for each step and are therefore called hk. Iterations of this algorithm are estimates of the position of the minimum, starting from an initial assumption ~ x0, which in this case is trivial the position of the robot at the start of the algorithm, and are therefore referred to as ~ xk. Thus, this algorithm is basically stateless and the current position of the robot is always the best estimate of the minimum.

sections.heading: 4.4 Motor Noise: Iteration Steps
sections.text: In addition to the effects of motor noise discussed in paragraph 3.3, the error in the actual movement of the robot must be taken into account when iterating the algorithm. Motor noise in the movement of the robot - provided it is truly random and unbiased - can be considered an additional error in the estimated (or measured) gradient of f (~ x). This discussion is similar to that in paragraph 3.3. This error is constant per unit length, but as the increment ak decreases, the resulting overall motion error also decreases. As the error increases with decreasing hk due to the central differential approximation (14), the motion error becomes irrelevant for large k and thus does not affect convergence.

sections.heading: 4.5 Other Stochastic Approximation Algorithms
sections.text: FDSA is only one algorithm from a family of stochastic approximation algorithms that exhibit similar properties and similar convergence conditions. It was chosen because of the intuitive formulation of the gradient estimation, which enabled us to discuss the properties of the estimated gradients in the light of our use of network robots. Other algorithms from this family work with different formulations for gradient estimation and can be proven as analytical convergence. They are known from the stochastic approximation literature [15] and have been successfully used in robotic contexts [13]. The detailed conditions for the convergence of these algorithms differ, but the basic constraints on the measured scalar field, as stated in Sec. 4.2, are the same for all algorithms from this family. Therefore, the discussion relating to wireless communication in Sec. 4.2 applies to the entire family of algorithms. sections.heading: 5 Experiments
sections.text: To show how to overcome the problems of small fades, we implemented the algorithm with a ground-based robot, for which the effects of small fades are much more severe than for a flying robot, since it can position itself with much higher precision (see also the discussion in Sec. 2.3).The algorithm was initially implemented with four measurements for each gradient estimate according to its original formulation.The resulting behavior was random and showed no convergence. The most likely reason for this behavior is the small fades due to its local periodic nature and the resulting effects on this naive gradient estimation. Since a robot must move from one sampling point to the next while executing the algorithm, we decided to use this motion and continuously measure it as it moves along the two axes of the gradient estimation. We supplemented the finite differential estimation of the derivatives with a linear model of the data collected along these lines.

sections.heading: 6 Adapting more Complex Objectives
sections.text: For this purpose, we choose a typical task in network robotics, namely bridging two network nodes, i.e. we move to the position between the nodes with maximum signal strength and equal signal strength to both nodes. This task often occurs when a gap in the network needs to be bridged. For this task, we define the objective function g (~ x) asg (~ x) asg (f1) − f2 (~ x) asc.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: This work showed that network robotics can use algorithms based on stochastic approximation that work with signal strength measurements for tasks such as navigation. We made estimates of the accuracy of gradients calculated from signal strength measurements. Measurements of signal strength and motor noise were physically motivated and their effects on the convergence of these algorithms were discussed in detail. We also implemented the algorithm experimentally to show how to deal with some of the specific challenges that network robotics presents, and we showed that more complex goals can be formulated within this framework.
